description: A simple 2-dimensional array, read by antidiagonals: T[i,j] = 1 for j>0, T[i,0] = i+1; i,j = 0,1,2,3...
comments: Warning: contributions from Kimberling refer to an alternate version indexed by 1 instead of 0. Other contributors (Adamson in A125026/A130301/A130295) refer to this considering the upper right triangle set to zero, T[i,j]=0 for j>i. - _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 15 2015A member of the accumulation chain:... < A051340 < A141419 < A185874 < A185875 < A185876 < ...(See A144112 for the definition of accumulation array.)In the m-th accumulation array of A051340,row_1 = C(m,1) and column_1 = C(1,m+1), for m>=0. - Clark Kimberling, Feb 05 2011
links: A. V. Mikhalev and A. A. Nechaev, Linear recurring sequences over modules, Acta Applic. Math., 42 (1996), 161-202.
formula: For n>0, a(n(n+3)/2)=n+1, and if k is not of the form n*(n+3)/2, then a(k)=1. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Oct 31 2002, corrected by _M. F. Hasler_, Aug 15 2015T(n,1)=n and T(n,k)=1 if k>1, for n>=1. - _Clark Kimberling_, Feb 05 2011
maple: A051340 := proc(n, k) if k=0 then n+1; else 1; end if; end proc: # _R. J. Mathar_, Jul 16 2015
